content.raw: On further thought, this may not be accurate. Strictly speaking, this gravity value is expressed in local tangent plane XYZ coordinates, whereas these may not correspond to ENU if a ```heading_offset``` is set in ```spherical_coordinates```. Likewise for magnetic field strength...
content.html: On further thought, this may not be accurate. Strictly speaking, this gravity value is expressed in local tangent plane XYZ coordinates, whereas these may not correspond to ENU if a heading_offset is set in spherical_coordinates. Likewise for magnetic field strength...

content.raw: Yip -- that's fine by me. I proposed microtesla only because the units were convenient. I read a while back that Gazebo strives for SI, which is why I asked in the issue I posted earlier.
content.html: Yip -- that's fine by me. I proposed microtesla only because the units were convenient. I read a while back that Gazebo strives for SI, which is why I asked in the issue I posted earlier.

content.raw: That's a good point. I forgot to mention @asymingt that we try to use SI (m, kg, s), so we should use tesla here and append `e-6` to the default values.
content.html: That's a good point. I forgot to mention @asymingt that we try to use SI (m, kg, s), so we should use tesla here and append e-6 to the default values.

content.raw: I think we could use either as long as we document the units properly. The earth's magnetic field magnitude ranges from 25-65 microtesla
content.html: I think we could use either as long as we document the units properly. The earth's magnetic field magnitude ranges from 25-65 microtesla

pull_request.title: Inclusion of magnetic field strength sensor

pullrequest.title: Inclusion of magnetic field strength sensor

content.raw:
Sounds good. In this case, my suggestion is to either:

 * be more description and explicitly list out `+X == East`, `+Y == North` and `+Z == Up` or
 * leaving out ENU specification for now, so we don't shoehorn ourselves into a specific category (e.g. if anyone is using gazebo in a non-ENU scenario right now... [nasa_r2_simulator](https://bitbucket.org/nasa_ros_pkg/nasa_r2_simulator/overview) comes to mind).
content.html:
Sounds good. In this case, my suggestion is to either:

  • be more description and explicitly list out +X == East, +Y == North and +Z == Up or
  • leaving out ENU specification for now, so we don't shoehorn ourselves into a specific category (e.g. if anyone is using gazebo in a non-ENU scenario right now... nasa_r2_simulator comes to mind).

content.raw:
can we make the coordinate frame an additional optional element or attribute?  E.g.

~~~
<gravity>0 0 0</gravity>
<world_coordinate_system>ENU</world_coordinate_system>
~~~
or
~~~
<gravity frame="world_coordinate_system">0 0 0</gravity>
~~~
content.html:
can we make the coordinate frame an additional optional element or attribute? E.g.

<gravity>0 0 0</gravity>
<world_coordinate_system>ENU</world_coordinate_system>

or

<gravity frame="world_coordinate_system">0 0 0</gravity>

content.raw:

@\_jrivero_ are we going to make a release from default any time soon?

This looks good to me. My only comment is about which release branch we should target. We have been targeting most pull requests recently to the sdf_2.0 branch.

@_jrivero_ are we going to make a release from default any time soon?
